intro: Dendrophthora biseriata, commonly known as the two-seeded mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of host trees, primarily in the genus *Eucalyptus*. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while also producing its own sugars through photosynthesis using light absorbed by its leaves. The plant produces small, white, fleshy fruits that contain two seeds, which are dispersed by birds. It is native to Australia and is often found in coastal and subtropical regions. Its parasitic nature and unique reproductive strategy make it an interesting subject for ecological studies.
